I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  2008  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical 
assistance (TA) to strengthen the enforcement of environmental laws and regulations in the 
PRC.1 In August 2009, an ADB mission visited the PRC and reached an understanding with the 
Government  on  the  TA  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The rapid economic development of the last 20 years, in combination with the PRC’s 
large population, has placed pressure on the PRC’s environment. Industries with high energy 
consumption and emissions pose increasing environmental threats, and constitute a growing 
challenge to environmental protection. Frequent, serious pollution incidents and poor on-site 
enforcement have resulted from (i) a lack of environmental awareness and understanding of 
environmental responsibilities on the part of some enterprises, (ii) easing of pollution controls by 
some local governments to favor economic growth, and (iii) a lack of effective supervisory 
capacity by responsible administrative authorities over relevant local departments.  
 
3.  To address these environmental challenges, over the years the PRC has strengthened 
its regulatory framework and enacted several environmental protection laws and regulations. 
While impressive progress has been made with respect to the development of an environmental 
regulatory  framework,  much  work  remains  to  be  done  with  regard  to  compliance  and 
enforcement. Environmental laws in the PRC are difficult to enforce, with enforcement occurring 
mainly through administrative procedures instead of the civil or criminal courts.2 Enforcement 
agencies  are  faced  with  growing  constraints  due  to  limited  capacity,  knowledge,  and 
enforcement experience. Some legislation have become outdated and irrelevant, and some are 
no longer effective. Many enforcement agencies in the PRC have been exploring alternative and 
more efficient rules and procedures.  
 
4.  In 1996, the PRC's State Environmental Protection Administration—which was upgraded 
in 2008 to the Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP)—adopted rules and procedures for 
environmental  supervision  to  guide  environmental  enforcement  agencies  nationwide.  To 
strengthen county- and city-level compliance in the field of environmental protection, MEP has 
established six regional environmental supervision and investigation institutes (RESIIs) since 
2006 to help local governments and relevant departments fulfill their responsibilities on behalf of 
MEP.  
 
5.  The progress achieved through the establishment of the RESIIs and MEP needs to be 
accompanied by (i) updating of the rules and procedures for environmental supervision, and (ii) 
the  introduction  of  innovative  approaches  to  environmental  compliance.  As  environmental 
awareness increases, public scrutiny is expected to intensify and this could reduce tolerance 
and  result  in  more  complaints  and  environmental  disputes.  This  highlights  the  need  for  a 
balance  between  (i)  creating  incentives  for  and  developing  the  capacity  of  environmental

enforcement agencies to handle public complaints, and (ii) placing greater demands on these 
agencies. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The  impact  of  the  proposed  TA  will  be  improved  environmental  management  and 
sustainable development in the PRC. The outcome of the TA will be a strengthened regulatory 
framework for environmental enforcement and compliance in the PRC. The TA will assist in 
mainstreaming environmental considerations into the PRC’s policies and investment programs, 
and in strengthening the legal, regulatory, and enforcement capacities of government agencies. 
The proposed TA is in line with ADB’s core area of operations as expressed in its long-term 
strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020)3 and the country partnership strategy (2008–
2010).4 The proposed TA supports the implementation of the Government’s 11th Five-Year Plan 
(FYP) (2006–2010), which emphasizes the need to build a society that uses resources efficiently 
and  is  environment-friendly.  While  environmental  challenges  in  the  PRC  are  diverse  and 
increasing, the 11th FYP seeks to reduce the emissions in 2005 of major pollutants by 10% by 
the end of 2010. The proposed TA will also contribute to the preparation of the 12th FYP (2011–
2015), which is expected to introduce new approaches for environmental protection in the PRC. 
 
7.  The  proposed  TA  builds  on  the  achievements  of  the  ADB-financed  Institutional 
Development of the State Environmental Protection Administration's RESII.5 This TA supported 
MEP  with  the  establishment  of  the  RESIIs,  the  development  of  strategic  road  maps  and 
institutional development plans, and the provision of training for the staff of MEP, RESIIs, and 
provincial  environmental  protection  bureaus.  The  proposed  TA  will  also  incorporate  the 
experiences  and  lessons  learned  from  the  (i)  support  that  ADB  provides  for  the  Asian 
Environmental Compliance and Enforcement Network6 to promote improved compliance with 
environmental policies, laws, and regulations through the exchange of innovative policies and 
practices; and (ii) ADB review of country safeguard systems.7 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The proposed TA will support the enforcement capacity of national, regional, and local 
enforcement agencies through analyses, assessments, recommendations, and training. The 
proposed TA will have three outputs.

forum participants. 
7  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Country Safeguard Systems. Manila (TA 6285-REG).

3
9.  Output 1: Innovative approaches to environmental enforcement and supervision 
in support of sustainable economic growth. A study will be conducted on how innovative 
approaches to environmental enforcement and supervision can be introduced in the PRC to 
support sustainable economic growth. This study will include 
 
(i)  a  review  of  international  experience  with  environmental  supervision  and 
compliance in France, the Republic of Korea, and the United Kingdom;8  
(ii)  an analysis of the potential application in the PRC of the specific environmental 
enforcement rules and work procedures in the selected countries; 
(iii)  a  review  of  the  role  of  civil  society  organizations  in  the  design  and 
implementation of compliance mechanisms; 
(iv)  a study tour to one of the case-study countries; 
(v)  recommendations for the PRC, based on the experiences and best practices of 
the countries studied; and 
(vi)  a published report on the role of innovative, and market-based enforcement and 
supervision approaches to support sustainable economic growth. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Updated  environmental  enforcement  and  supervision  rules  and 
procedures. The TA will help MEP update the existing rules and procedures for environmental 
enforcement  and  supervision,  taking  into  account  the  current  institutional  setting  and  the 
findings of the study on innovative approaches. Updating the enforcement and supervision rules 
and procedures is part of the responsibility of MEP's Department of Environmental Enforcement 
and Inspection. MEP's work procedures for environmental supervision cover the (i) pollution 
source, (ii) pollution control facilities, (iii) construction activities, (iv) project compliance, (v) 
permit issuance and compliance, (vi) discharge fee collection, (vii) management and use of 
environmental grants, (viii) on-site penalties, (ix) administrative penalties, (x) environmental 
pollution and damages investigation and response, and (xi) environmental dispute investigation 
and response. This output also aims to (i) establish an updated framework for the actions of 
environmental enforcement agencies, (ii) specify the duties of these agencies, and (iii) formulate 
differentiated work rules and procedures for these agencies at all levels based on their authority 
and duties.  
 
11.  The activities will include 
 
(i)  a review of the current environmental enforcement and supervision rules and 
procedures  in  light  of  the  changes  in  environmental  management  systems, 
operational mechanisms, and models of enforcement supervision; 
(ii)  a rapid capacity assessment of the institutional capacity of the six RESIIs; 
(iii)  preparation  of  recommendations  and  proposals  regarding  the  rules  and 
procedures to be withdrawn and to be reformulated, including, where applicable, 
specific sections dealing with the major industries (e.g., petrochemical, paper-
making, thermal power plants, and pharmaceutical); and 
(iv)  preparation of environmental enforcement supervision rules and procedures. The 
updated rules and procedures will be submitted to MEP for issuance after the 
endorsement by a TA steering committee. 
 
                                                 
8 The final selection of the case studies will be made by MEP and ADB during the inception phase, in consultation 
with the TA consultants. The criteria for selection will include the historical similarities with the PRC in terms of 
development, regulatory system, and environmental threats.

4   
12.  Output 3: Training manuals, awareness-raising materials, and training. Training 
and awareness materials will be prepared for the introduction of the updated supervision rules 
and procedures at the regional and local levels. The activities will include 
 
(i)  consultations with experts and enforcers;  
(ii)  preparation of training manuals and awareness materials for specific sectors; 
(iii)  organization  of  seminars  on  enforcement  procedures  for  the  four  major 
industries; and 
(iv)  preparation  and  implementation  of  training-of-trainers  workshops  for  the  six 
RESIIs  covering  the  rules  and  work  procedures  for  improved  environmental 
supervision, including dispute resolution. It is anticipated that about 24 trainers 
will be trained.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $400,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested that ADB finance $300,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program (TASF-Others). The Government will finance the balance of the 
cost, equivalent to $100,000, through the provision of necessary data, office space, counterpart 
staff, local transportation, and other administrative support. The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed  in  line  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook.9  The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 12 months, from January to December 
2010. MEP will be the executing agency (EA). A TA steering committee will be established in 
MEP, chaired by the Deputy Director General of the Department of Environmental Enforcement 
and Inspection and comprised of representatives from relevant departments. It will provide 
overall guidance for TA implementation and endorse TA outputs. A TA management office will 
be established in the Foreign Economic Cooperation Office (FECO) of MEP, headed by the 
Director of Division 1, and comprise one full-time FECO staff member and other staff members 
appointed from relevant MEP departments. The TA management office will be responsible for 
day-to-day operational matters among ADB, consultants, and related MEP departments and 
government agencies.  
 
15.  A team of consultants will be recruited for a total of 33 person-months, comprising 1 
international expert for 3 person-months and 4 national experts for 30 person-months. The TA is 
intended to be partially delegated to the EA. The consultants will be recruited by the EA and 
contracted by ADB using the individual selection method in accordance with ADB's Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Individual engagements are 
considered  to  be  more  economical  and  efficient  for  the  TA.  MEP  has  experience  in 
implementing ADB TA projects and is capable of undertaking the selection of consultants in 
accordance with ADB's policies, guidelines, and procedures.10 Equipment will be procured by 
the EA in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time).  Ownership  of  the  equipment  will  be  transferred  to  the  EA  upon  TA  completion.

10 A capacity assessment of the Ministry of Environmental Protection conducted by ADB in June 2008 showed that it 
has the capacity to implement the delegated authority.

5
Operational expenses for training, workshops, study tours, and translation will be included in the 
consultants' contracts. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
16.  Implementation progress will be monitored through (i) ADB's inception, interim, and final 
review  missions;  (ii)  workshops  and  seminars;  and  (iii)  draft  and  final  project  reports  and 
publications. The findings under the TA will be disseminated through workshops, seminars, and 
disclosure of the final reports on the websites of FECO and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People's  Republic  of  China  for  Strengthening  Enforcement  of 
Environmental Laws and Regulations, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  A team of consultants will be recruited for a total of 33 person-months, comprising 1 
international and 4 national experts. The consultants will be engaged by the executing agency in 
accordance with the Bank's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time 
to time), using the individual selection method.  
2.  Table  A3  summarizes  the  estimated  international  and  national  consultant  inputs 
required.

  Person-Months 
Expertise  International  National

Training Specialist    5 
  Total  3       30

B.  Terms of Reference 
3.  Team leader and environmental regulatory specialist (national, 10 person-months). 
The  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall  coordination  and  supervision  of  the 
consultant team. The team leader will have experience in the People's Republic of China (PRC) 
and abroad, and will have a good understanding of the PRC's environmental and administrative 
laws and regulations, environmental enforcement system, implementation mechanisms, and 
detailed work procedures. The team leader will have project management expertise. The team 
leader will 
(i)  act as the main liaison between the Ministry of Environmental Protection and the 
consultant team; 
(ii)  manage and ensure the timely implementation of the technical assistance (TA); 
(iii)  coordinate the individual studies and consolidate the reports; 
(iv)  compile and finalize the TA inception, midterm, and final reports; 
(v)  coordinate the design, assessment, and revision of environmental enforcement 
work rules and procedures; 
(vi)  as the lead expert, assume final responsibility for the preparation of the updated 
environmental enforcement and supervision rules and procedures; 
(vii)  identify and discuss related supporting training materials; 
(viii)  participate and present relevant topics in project seminars and workshops; and 
(ix)  compile and finalize the TA final report. 
4.  The team leader will submit an inception report by month 2, a midterm report by month 
7, and a final report summarizing the findings and recommendations of the TA by month 12. All 
reports and training materials will be submitted in Chinese and English. 
 
5.  Environmental economist (national, 7 person-months). The environmental economist 
will have experience with the development and implementation of market-based instruments in 
environmental enforcement and compliance in the PRC. The economist will have the main

10  Appendix 3 
responsibility  for  conducting  the  special  study  on  innovative  approaches  to  ensure 
environmental compliance while promoting economic growth. The economist will 
(i)  analyze  foreign  case  studies  on  economic  growth  and  environmental 
enforcement; 
(ii)  assess  the  PRC's  relevant  institutional  and  regulatory  framework  and  policy 
development-related institutions; 
(iii)  propose recommendations for changing environmental enforcement philosophies 
and theories to optimize economic growth through environmental enforcement in 
the current PRC context; 
(iv)  contribute to the preparation of relevant sections of the framework for improved 
enforcement rules and procedures; 
(v)  contribute to the drafting of the inception, midterm, and final TA reports; 
(vi)  prepare the final study report on the role of innovative enforcement approaches 
to support economic growth; 
(vii)  participate and present relevant topics in project seminars and workshops; and 
(viii)  conduct other related tasks as requested by the team leader.  
6.  The  environmental  economist  will  submit  a  draft  report  on  the  role  of  innovative 
enforcement approaches to support economic growth by month 4. The final report will be 
submitted by month 8 after incorporating the comments and feedback received during the 
midterm workshop. All reports will be submitted in Chinese and English. 
 
7.  Environmental  compliance  expert  (international,  3  person-months).  The 
environmental  compliance  expert  will  have  international  experience  in  environmental 
enforcement, including in the PRC. The expert will support the team leader and other team 
members in providing technical support for and incorporating international experience into the 
framework for project documents. The expert will 
(i)  conduct  a  survey  of  international  experience  in  environmental  enforcement 
applicable to the PRC;  
(ii)  support the team leader in the design, assessment, and revision of environmental 
enforcement work rules and procedures; 
(iii)  support  the  team  leader  in  identifying  and  discussing  related  supporting  and 
training materials; 
(iv)  contribute to the drafting of the inception, midterm, and final TA reports; 
(v)  participate and present relevant topics in project seminars and workshops; and 
(vi)  conduct other related tasks as requested by the team leader.  
8.  The expert will prepare contributions for the different project reports and will summarize 
the contributions in an end-of-assignment report by month 12. The report will be submitted in 
English. 
 
9.  Industrial pollution control expert (national, 8 person-months). The expert will have 
experience  with  pollution  prevention  and  control  technologies  in  key  industries  (e.g., 
petrochemical, paper-making, thermal power plants, and pharmaceutical). The expert will 
(i)  in cooperation with the team leader, review and prepare an updated framework for 
environmental supervision rules and procedures; 
(ii)  support  the  team  leader  in  identifying  and  preparing  training  materials  to 
complement  updated  enforcement  rules  and  procedures,  with  a  focus  on  the 
specific requirements for the key industries;  
(iii)  in cooperation with the training specialist, prepare training materials;

(iv)  organize and conduct seminars with four major industries (i.e., petrochemical, 
paper-making, thermal power plants, and pharmaceutical); 
(v)  contribute to the drafting of the inception, midterm, and final TA reports; 
(vi)  participate and present relevant topics in project training workshops; and 
(vii)  conduct other related tasks as requested by the team leader.  
10.  The industrial pollution control expert, in cooperation with the training specialist, will 
submit seminar reports detailing the feedback received from the major industries (in English and 
Chinese by month 8). After conducting the training of trainers in six regional environmental 
supervision and investigation institutes (RESIIs), the expert will provide support to finalize the 
training reports and materials by incorporating the experience and feedback received during the 
training workshops. All reports will be submitted in Chinese and English. 
 
11.  Training specialist (national, 5 person-months). The specialist will have experience 
with environmental enforcement research or practical enforcement activities in the PRC. The 
specialist will understand the specific work procedures used for environmental enforcement in 
the PRC and the general work procedures used for environmental enforcement internationally. 
In consultation with the team leader, the specialist will 
(i)  conduct a rapid capacity assessment of the RESIIs; 
(ii)  prepare training materials to complement the updated rules and procedures; 
(iii)  prepare and conduct the training-of-trainers sessions; 
(iv)  contribute to the drafting of the inception, midterm, and final TA reports; 
(v)  participate and present relevant topics in project seminars and workshops; and 
(vi)  conduct other related tasks as requested by the team leader.  
 
12.  The training specialist, in cooperation with the industrial pollution control expert, will 
submit  draft  training  and  awareness  materials  in  English  and  Chinese  by  month  8.  After 
conducting the training of trainers in six RESIIs, the specialist will finalize the training and 
awareness materials by incorporating the experience and feedback received during the training 
workshops. All reports and training materials will be submitted in Chinese and English.
